p: Radical scavenging activity (RSA) of the medicinal honeys was recorded by determining the reduction in radical 2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) following Meda et al. [ 33]. Honey was diluted in methanol and filtered with a 0.45 µm sterile Millex filter (Merk, Bayswater, VIC, Australia). Then, 0.8 mL of a 2.5% honey solution ( w/ v) was added to 2.7 mL of 0.024 mg/mL DPPH in methanol. The mixture was vigorously shaken for 15 s and incubated for 30 min without light at room temperature. The DPPH reduction was read at 517 nm absorbance using a Lambda 35 UV–vis spectrophotometer (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, MA, USA). RSA was the percentage of DPPH discoloration calculated from the equation: % RSA = [(ADPPH − AS)/ADPPH] × 100 (1) where ADPPH and AS are the absorbance units of DPPH solutions in the absence and presence of honey, respectively.
